author: By Michael Paulson
title: Nonprofit Theaters Are in Trouble. Lawmakers Are Proposing Help.
description: Proposed legislation would allocate $1 billion annually for an industry coping with rising expenses and smaller audiences.
content: The financial crisis facing nonprofit theaters in America has captured the attention of Congress, where a group of Democratic lawmakers is introducing legislation that would direct $1 billion annually to the struggling industry for five years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Igielnik
title: More Voters Shift to Republican Party, Closing Gap With Democrats
description: The trend toward the Republican Party among white voters without a college degree has continued, and Democrats have lost ground among Hispanic voters, too.
content: In the run-up to the 2020 election, more voters across the country identified as Democrats than Republicans. But four years into Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s presidency, that gap has shrunk, and the United States now sits almost evenly divided between Democrats and Republicans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: What Happened When a German Car Factory Went All Electric
description: Volkswagen’s plant in Zwickau stopped producing Golfs and switched to electric vehicles, illuminating the risks and opportunities for factory towns and cities.
content: Zwickau, a city in Germany’s east, may not be as famous as Detroit, but its economy has revolved around internal combustion engines since August Horch established Audi here at the beginning of the 20th century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: More Funding Needed to Prosecute Pandemic Fraud, Justice Dept. Says
description: The Justice Department said more than $1.4 billion in stolen relief funds have been seized or forfeited. But estimates of the total stolen run into the tens of billions.
content: More resources are needed to investigate and prosecute individuals who stole billions in pandemic relief funds, the Justice Department said in a report on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Wednesday Briefing: A Divided South Korea Votes
description: Also, a landmark climate ruling in Europe.
content: South Koreans are heading to the polls today to ​select a new Parliament after a particularly fraught campaign. The general election, the first since President Yoon Suk-yeol won the presidency in 2022, is seen as a midterm referendum on his leadership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: The Magnetic Fields Wrote ‘69 Love Songs.’ Here’s 11 of the Best.
description: A primer on the indie-rock band’s triple album, now celebrating its 25th anniversary.
content: I hope everyone who was in the path of Monday’s eclipse enjoyed the view! I confess I didn’t acquire eclipse glasses in time and couldn’t see anything too spectacular from where I was in Brooklyn, but at least Friday’s Amplifier playlist gave me a soundtrack for imagining some awe-inspiring grandeur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Maag
title: A Divided America Agrees on One Thing: The Eclipse Was Awesome
description: The solar eclipse helped unite America — or at least a very narrow band of it.
content: Aidan Hernandez lay on the sidewalk wearing his eclipse glasses and staring up. The day was cloudy in Eagle Pass, Texas, and for a while he was silent. Then the clouds parted and the sun appeared, obscured by the moon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Lashbrook
title: A Father and a Daughter, Caught Up in Political Protests
description: In Jen Silverman’s new novel, “There’s Going to Be Trouble,” two generations of activists wrestle with the errors of the past as they strive to create a more survivable future.
content: I recently gave birth, and there are moments when I look at my son and feel the heavy knowledge that he will carry the burden of my mistakes. In other moments there’s lightness, for motherhood, in just a few months, has taught me that my influence is limited, despite my best attempts and biggest failures. That dichotomy is at the core of Jen Silverman’s smart, reflective new novel, “There’s Going to Be Trouble,” which follows two generations of activists wrestling with the errors of the past as they strive to draft a more survivable future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Pang, Priya Krishna and Brian Gallagher
title: The 25 Best Restaurants in Chicago Right Now
description: We scouted the city’s vast food scene, from stellar hot dogs and renowned Italian beefs to refined tasting menus. (And we’re here for your comments.).
content: In the Where to Eat: 25 Best series, we’re highlighting our favorite restaurants in cities across the United States. These lists will be updated as restaurants close and open, and as we find new gems to recommend. As always, we pay for all of our meals and don’t accept free items.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By T.M. Brown
title: Want to See This Film? Movie Studios Won’t Let You.
description: As in the case of ‘Coyote vs. Acme,’ sometimes an entertainment company sees more value in not selling you its products.
content: In early February, strange news appeared about Warner Brothers Discovery’s plans for one of its films, a live-action-with-animation spin on Looney Tunes called “Coyote vs. Acme.” The studio did not plan to release the movie. It had tried to sell it to a third party — one industry report said Netflix, Amazon and Paramount were all interested — but no deal materialized. Audiences seemed unlikely to ever see the thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marlise Simons, Erika Solomon and Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Germany Rebuffs Claim Its Arms Sales to Israel Abet Genocide in Gaza
description: Germany argued against the accusation brought by Nicaragua at the International Court of Justice, but Germans are questioning their country’s unwavering support for Israel.
content: Germany on Tuesday defended itself against accusations that its arms sales to Israel were abetting genocide in Gaza, arguing at the International Court of Justice that most of the equipment it has supplied since Oct. 7 was nonlethal and that it has also been one of the largest donors of humanitarian aid to the Palestinians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Ben Protess, Natasha Singer, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and James Shield
title: Trump’s Calculus on Abortion, and Iran’s Secret Smuggling Network
description: Plus, the fight against “deepnudes.”
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump’s New Stance on Abortion
description: Readers discuss his statement that abortion policy should be left to the states. Also: J Street; student “brands”; GPS satellites; alternatives to social media.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman
title: Woman Sentenced to Month in Prison Over Theft of Ashley Biden’s Diary
description: Aimee Harris sold the diary to Project Veritas, a right-wing group, in what prosecutors said was a brazen plot to damage Joseph R. Biden Jr. in the 2020 election.
content: A federal judge in Manhattan sentenced a Florida woman on Tuesday to one month behind bars for her role in a brazen scheme to steal the diary of President Biden’s daughter and sell it to a right-wing group in the hope of disrupting the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Here Comes the Sun. And There It Goes.
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, April 9, 2024.
content: “It puts perspective in the universe, perspective in your life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Prosecutors Ask Supreme Court to Reject Trump’s Immunity Claim in Election Case
description: The filing was the main submission from Jack Smith, the special counsel prosecuting the former president. The case will be argued on April 25.
content: Jack Smith, the special counsel prosecuting former President Donald J. Trump on charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election, urged the Supreme Court on Monday to reject Mr. Trump’s claim that he is immune from prosecution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Clarence Henry, New Orleans R&B Star Known as the Frogman, Dies at 87
description: A local hero in his hometown, he was best known for his hit “Ain’t Got No Home,” which showcased the vocal versatility that earned him his nickname.
content: Clarence Henry, the New Orleans rhythm-and-blues mainstay who was known as Frogman — and best known for boasting in his durable 1956 hit, “Ain’t Got No Home,” that “I sing like a girl/ And I sing like a frog” — died on Sunday. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marlise Simons, Christopher F. Schuetze and Erika Solomon
title: At U.N. Court, Germany Fights Allegations of Aiding Genocide
description: Nicaragua has accused Germany over its provision of military and financial aid to Israel. Germany said the case had “no basis in fact or law.”
content: Germany on Tuesday defended itself at the International Court of Justice against accusations that its arms shipments to Israel were furthering genocide in Gaza, arguing that most of the equipment it has supplied since Oct. 7 was nonlethal and that it has also been one of the largest donors of humanitarian aid to the Palestinians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Arizona Reinstated a 160-Year-Old Abortion Ban
description: Also, Iran is smuggling weapons into the West Bank. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: Arizona’s highest court today ruled that an 1864 law that bans nearly all abortions “is now enforceable.” With the federal right to abortion now overturned, the justices explained, there was nothing stopping the state from reinstating its long-dormant prohibition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold, Mara Hvistendahl, Rikki Novetsky, Mooj Zadie, Rachelle Bonja, Lisa Chow, Alexandra Leigh Young, Marion Lozano, Diane Wong, Elisheba Ittoop, Sophia Lanman and Chris Wood
title: How Tesla Planted the Seeds for Its Own Potential Downfall
description: Elon Musk’s factory in China saved his company and made him ultrarich. Now, it may backfire.
content: When Elon Musk set up Tesla’s factory in China, he made a bet that brought him cheap parts and capable workers — a bet that made him ultrarich and saved his company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias
title: Looking Up, Together
description: We cover the solar eclipse that captivated the U.S.
content: As the moon crossed over the sun yesterday, millions of people from Mazatlán to Maine stopped to gaze upward in a profound experience of awe. The solar eclipse tapped into a primal emotion. It evoked for many a mystical moment, as awareness of the celestial encompassed the earth. It revealed the close dance between spirituality and science.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dylan Loeb McClain
title: Herbert Kroemer, 95, Dies; Laid Groundwork for Modern Technologies
description: He shared a Nobel Prize in Physics for discoveries that paved the way for high-speed internet communication, mobile phones and bar-code readers.
content: Herbert Kroemer, a German-born American physicist who was awarded the Nobel Prize for his part in discoveries that paved the way for the development of many trappings of modern life, including high-speed internet communication, mobile phones and bar-code readers, died on March 8. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Oshetsky
title: Is This Maternity Hospital Haunted, or Is It All a Pregnant Metaphor?
description: In Clare Beams’s eerie new novel, “The Garden,” nefarious things are afoot.
content: THE GARDEN, by Clare Beams
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Barker, Jonah E. Bromwich and Michael Rothfeld
title: How Alvin Bragg Hitched His Fate to Trump’s
description: The Manhattan D.A. campaigned as the best candidate to go after the former president. Now he finds himself leading Trump’s first prosecution — and perhaps the only one before the November election.
content: Reporters vied for seats in the briefing room, some even crouching on the floor. They all knew, on this Tuesday in early April 2023, that Alvin L. Bragg, the Manhattan district attorney, was about to announce something momentous: the first criminal charges against a former American president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Greene Escalates Threat Against Johnson, Making the Case for His Ouster
description: In a letter to Republicans, the far-right lawmaker from Georgia said the speaker had presided over a “complete and total surrender” to Democrats and President Biden, and must change course or be unseated.
content: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene on Tuesday escalated her threat to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, distributing a scathing letter that made the case for his removal and took Republicans to task for tolerating his leadership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: Bill in Congress Would Force Action on U.S. Troops’ Blast Exposure
description: The Pentagon would be required to modify weapons, update safety guidelines, train medical staff and track individual troops’ exposure to repeated blasts that can injure their brains.
content: Lawmakers from both parties plan to introduce a sweeping bill in Congress on Wednesday that would force the military for the first time to track and limit troops’ exposure to damaging shock waves from firing their own weapons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: Norfolk Southern Settles Derailment Suit for $600 Million
description: The railroad company will pay residents and businesses in East Palestine, Ohio, and the surrounding area after a derailment last year.
content: Norfolk Southern announced on Tuesday that it had agreed to pay $600 million to settle a class-action lawsuit stemming from a February 2023 derailment of a train carrying hazardous materials in East Palestine, Ohio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: A Historian Makes Peace With Her Own History
description: It took Doris Kearns Goodwin a while to adjust to leaving the Concord, Mass., farmhouse she shared with her husband. But Boston has its compensations.
content: After Doris Kearns Goodwin’s husband died nearly six years ago, the couple’s home, a 19th-century farmhouse in Concord, Mass., no longer felt right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: Austin Pushes Back on Claims of Israel Carrying Out Genocide in Gaza
description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III made the comments during a hearing that was disrupted several times by protests of U.S. support for Israel’s assault on Hamas.
content: Secretary of Defense Lloyd J. Austin III told a Senate committee on Tuesday that the Pentagon had no evidence that Israel was carrying out a genocide against Palestinians in the Gaza Strip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Shogun’ Episode 8 Recap: Borrowed Time
description: As Toranaga trudges toward surrender, his closest allies wonder if the old samurai has really given up the fight.
content: Lord Toranaga is a sick man. Sick in his heart, grieving the loss of his son Nagakado, who died in a vain fight on his father’s behalf. Sick in his body, having contracted an illness on the long road back to Edo for Nagakado’s burial. The central scene of this week’s “Shogun” — perhaps the scene from the series so far — confronts vassal and viewer alike with an even more troubling question, one that it draws out for minute after excruciating minute: Is Lord Toranaga sick in his mind as well?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Alcorn
title: Should Alcoholic Beverages Have Cancer Warning Labels?
description: Ireland will require them starting in 2026, and there are nascent efforts elsewhere to add more explicit labeling about the health risks of drinking.
content: Fifteen words  are roiling the global alcohol industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Gypsy Rose Blanchard Files for Divorce From Ryan Anderson
description: The couple married while Ms. Blanchard, who was found guilty of helping to kill her mother, was still in prison.
content: Gypsy Rose Blanchard, who was convicted of helping to kill her abusive mother in a widely covered case, filed for divorce Monday from Ryan Anderson after just under two years of marriage, according to Louisiana court records.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 9, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, April 9, 2024.
content: An article on Saturday about an earthquake that struck the Northeast described incorrectly a trip to the Empire State Building by Clara Dossetter and David Dossetter. Mr. Dossetter was visiting from San Francisco, but Ms. Dossetter lives in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘That Was a Fake Question’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: In the yellow house on San Marco Drive, my father did my taxes. “Do you have your receipts from the move?” he asked. That was a fake question. The real questions were stacked behind it: Are you your father’s daughter? Are your affairs — is your life — in order? “Yes,” I said proudly, producing an envelope of gasoline and fast-food receipts from my drive south, Pennsylvania to Florida. A financial diary of my fresh start. “Good girl,” he said. With him 20 years gone, I repeat those words to myself when I need his gentle hand on my back. — Maggie Galehouse
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: An Elementary School Tries a ‘Radical’ Idea: Staying Open 12 Hours a Day
description: A Brooklyn charter school is experimenting with a new way to help families by expanding the school day. Students can arrive at 7 a.m. and leave any time before 7 p.m. For free.
content: It sounds like a dream for some working parents: school for 12 hours a day, starting bright and early at 7 a.m. and ending after dinner, at 7 p.m., all completely free.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden, Rachel Chaundler and Tariq Panja
title: Security Increased for Champions League Games After ISIS Threats
description: Online messages urged violent attacks on four matches, prompting the police in England, France and Spain to step up precautions.
content: Public safety officials in England, France and Spain said Tuesday that they would step up security for matches this week in the Champions League, Europe’s marquee soccer competition, after ISIS-related groups called for violent attacks on the contests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Nolan
title: For Jonathan Majors, a Year of Counseling
description: Majors, who has starred in Marvel movies, was found guilty of assaulting and harassing his then girlfriend. He avoided jail time.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at the sentencing of Jonathan Majors, an actor who has appeared in Marvel movies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Mount Etna Puffs Perfect Smoke Rings Into Sicilian Sky
description: The volcano, one of Europe’s most active, has been spewing volcanic vortex rings at a rapid pace. But that doesn’t mean a big explosion is on the way, one expert says.
content: For just over a week, Mount Etna, one of Europe’s most active volcanoes, has been spewing circular, mostly white smoke rings into the skies over Sicily.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Beyoncé, ‘Cowboy Carter’ and Filling in History’s Gaps
description: A conversation about how the pop superstar’s genre experiments explore race and power, and the implicit politics that come with them.
content: Last month, Beyoncé released “Cowboy Carter,” an album that tackles the whole of American music, using country, roots and Americana as jumping off points for explorations of race and power and the implicit politics that come with them. It is currently the No. 1 album in the country, with the biggest debut week of the year so far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Higher for Longer After All? Investors See Fed Rates Falling More Slowly.
description: Investors went into 2024 expecting the Federal Reserve to cut rates sharply. Stubborn inflation and quick growth call that into question.
content: Investors were betting big on Federal Reserve rate cuts at the start of 2024, wagering that central bankers would lower interest rates to around 4 percent by the end of the year. But after months of stubborn inflation and strong economic growth, the outlook is starting to look much less dramatic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: Is Apple Cider Vinegar Really a Cure-All?
description: It has been said to help with weight loss, blood sugar control, acne and more. But experts say the science is more nuanced.
content: On TikTok, a man swirls a tablespoon of apple cider vinegar into a cup of water, drinks it and eats two slices of pizza. Then, he tests his blood sugar. “These are the best results of all,” he says, showing a much lower spike on a blood sugar graph than when he ate the pizza without the vinegar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Miller
title: The Culture Warriors Are Coming for You Smart People
description: In Lionel Shriver’s new novel, judging intelligence and competence is a form of bigotry.
content: As a novelist, Lionel Shriver has made her strongest impressions selecting some hot issue of the day — school shootings, the American health care system, the ballooning of the U.S. national debt — and working it into a well-paced drama about its effects on one family. When this formula works, as it did best with “We Need to Talk About Kevin” (2003), the result can be riveting and also very popular. The intimacy of domestic politics moderates Shriver’s polemical side, which, when given free rein — as during an infamous 2016 speech she gave on cultural appropriation while wearing a sombrero — usually turns out to be smug, crude and obtuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: German Business Is Tangled in Red Tape
description: Companies in Germany complain that the demands of bureaucracy are costing them time and money that would be better spent building their businesses.
content: When Markus Wingens created the position of “energy manager” for the metal heat-treatment company he runs in southwestern Germany, his idea was to increase energy efficiency and attract customers interested in sustainability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Piotr Jasiński
title: The Geopolitics of a Czech-Polish Potato Salad Competition
description: In the midst of a political and environmental dispute between the Czech Republic and Poland over a coal mine, a potato salad contest is held in a small border town.
content: In the fall of 2021, a pub in the mining town of Bogatynia, Poland, put up a sign: “We don’t serve Czechs.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Nazaryan
title: New Method That Pinpoints Wood’s Origin May Curb Illegal Timber
description: The study could help identify wood from Russia, which has been banned by many countries because of the war.
content: Using a unique combination of old-fashioned field work and sophisticated computer modeling, scientists in Sweden have found a way to trace a single beam of lumber to the forest in Europe where it originated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Kornei
title: Someday, Earth Will Have a Final Total Solar Eclipse
description: The moon will drift far enough from Earth that it no longer fully obstructs the sun. But predicting when this will happen poses numerous challenges.
content: The total solar eclipse visible on Monday over parts of Mexico, the United States and Canada was a perfect confluence of the sun and the moon in the sky. But it’s also the kind of event that comes with an expiration date: At some point in the distant future, Earth will experience its last total solar eclipse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathaniel Rich
title: Climate Change Is Making Us Paranoid, Anxious and Angry
description: From dolphins with Alzheimer’s to cranky traffic judges, writes Clayton Page Aldern, the whole planet is going berserk.
content: We know, often with abject precision, what climate change is doing to our coasts, rainforests, wildfires and hurricanes; our immigration patterns, crop yields and insurance premiums. But what is it doing to our brains?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Three Greenhouse Gases, Three All-Time Highs
description: Why emissions hit record levels last year.
content: The extreme weather. The melting glaciers. The weirdly warm oceans. They’re all the product of global warming, which is being driven by the release of the three most important heat-trapping gases: carbon dioxide, methane and nitrous oxide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Internet Traffic Dipped as Viewers Took in the Eclipse
description: Internet traffic dropped by 40 percent or more during the eclipse in states in the path of totality, including Maine, New Hampshire and Ohio, Cloudflare found.
content: As the moon blocked the view of the sun across parts of Mexico, the United States and Canada on Monday, the celestial event managed another magnificent feat: It got people offline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: California Is in Bloom Again
description: Wildflowers are beginning to spring to life across the state after another wet winter.
content: Spring has sprung in the Golden State.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Katie Thomas
title: Michigan Vascular Clinics Shutting Down After Scrutiny
description: The clinics’ owner, Dr. Jihad Mustapha, who called himself the “leg saver” but whose procedures sometimes preceded amputations, was a focus of a Times investigation last year.
content: A doctor who called himself the “leg saver” is shutting down his vascular clinics in Michigan, where he performed thousands of lucrative procedures that have come under scrutiny for being unnecessary and potentially dangerous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Seriously, Now Is the Time to Stop Kissing Sick Birds
description: A citizen-science collaboration in New York has turned up a half-dozen birds infected with the avian flu virus.
content: New Yorkers, beware: If you come across a bird or animal that is sick, dead or behaving strangely, keep yourself and your pets at a safe distance. The bird flu virus, H5N1, is present in at least some small fraction of New York City birds, according to a new study.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meaghan Tobin, Hisako Ueno and John Liu
title: How Japan Is Trying to Rebuild Its Chip Industry
description: Taiwan’s semiconductor giant, TSMC, is quickly remaking a farm town in Japan into Asia’s next hub of chip manufacturing with enormous government support.
content: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company is transforming the small Japanese farm town of Kikuyo into a key node in Asia’s chip supply chain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: To Cut Cancer Risks, E.P.A. Limits Pollution From Chemical Plants
description: The new regulation is aimed at reducing the risk of cancer for people who live close to plants emitting toxic chemicals.
content: More than 200 chemical plants across the country will be required to curb the toxic pollutants they release into the air under a regulation announced by the Biden administration on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy and George Gene Gustines
title: Comics Artist Dies After Sexual Misconduct Accusations
description: Ed Piskor, 41, was known for his detailed “Hip Hop Family Tree” and “X-Men: Grand Design.” A Pittsburgh gallery didn’t open an exhibition of his work after the initial allegation.
content: The comics artist Ed Piskor, who was best known for his multivolume “Hip Hop Family Tree,” died last week after posting a lengthy note to social media about an accusation of sexual misconduct that led a gallery in Pittsburgh to indefinitely postpone an exhibition of his work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman
title: As Kushner’s Investment Firm Steps Out, the Potential Conflicts Are Growing
description: Jared Kushner’s Affinity Partners has invested more than $1.2 billion, much of it in firms abroad, drawing new scrutiny as his father-in-law, Donald Trump, again seeks the presidency.
content: Jared Kushner’s investment fund is not especially large by global finance standards. But as he gets it fully up and running, each step is bringing with it ethical issues that would only grow if his father-in-law, Donald J. Trump, should win another term as president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Canada Wants to Regulate Online Content. Critics Say It Goes Too Far.
description: A bill introduced by the Canadian government to safeguard against online harms has stirred opposition from free speech advocates.
content: Canada has waded into the contentious issue of regulating online content with a sweeping proposal that would force technology companies to restrict and remove harmful material, especially posts involving children, that appears on their platforms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Swing-State Republicans Embrace Trump’s New Abortion Stance
description: Several of the party’s candidates, particularly those in battleground states, said they favored letting states regulate the procedure instead of having a national ban.
content: Multiple Republican candidates in swing-state races aligned themselves with former President Donald J. Trump after he said abortion access should be left up to the states, avoiding mention of a national ban and laying bare the party’s rift over the issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker and James Glanz
title: F.A.A. Investigates Claims by Boeing Whistle-Blower About Flaws in 787 Dreamliner
description: The whistle-blower, an engineer, says that sections of the plane’s body are being assembled in a way that could weaken the aircraft over time. Boeing says there is no safety issue.
content: The Federal Aviation Administration is investigating claims made by a Boeing engineer who says that sections of the fuselage of the 787 Dreamliner are improperly fastened together and could break apart mid-flight after thousands of trips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ralph Blumenthal
title: What’s Next for Jane Goodall? An Immersive Spectacle in Tanzania.
description: “Dr. Jane’s Dream” is going up in East Africa, where visitors can experience the primatologist’s scientific breakthroughs (complete with termite mound).
content: Are you ready for the Jane Goodall Experience?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Former Trump Fund-Raiser Drops Suits Over Hack of Emails
description: Elliott Broidy had filed lawsuits against a former C.I.A. officer and three lobbyists accusing them of helping Qatar engineer the theft and distribution of his communications to discredit him.
content: Elliott Broidy, a California businessman who was once a top fund-raiser for Donald J. Trump, dropped two lawsuits on Monday against people he accused of helping to carry out a hack-and-leak operation that revealed his covert lobbying to shape the Trump administration’s foreign policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: Peter Higgs, Nobelist Who Predicted the ‘God Particle,’ Dies at 94
description: The Higgs boson was named for him. It was a key element of the Standard Model, which encapsulated all human knowledge so far about elementary particles.
content: Peter Higgs, who predicted the existence of a new particle that came to be named after him (as well as God) and sparked a half-century, worldwide, billion-dollar search for it culminating in champagne in 2012 and a Nobel Prize a year later, died on Monday at home in Edinburgh, Scotland. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin and Anna Betts
title: Parents of Michigan School Shooter Sentenced to 10 to 15 Years in Prison
description: Jennifer and James Crumbley, whose son killed four people, each faced up to 15 years in prison for involuntary manslaughter convictions.
content: Jennifer and James Crumbley, who were convicted of involuntary manslaughter for failing to prevent their teenage son from killing four fellow students in the deadliest school shooting in Michigan’s history, were each sentenced on Tuesday to 10 to 15 years in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden’s Trade Moves Raise Tensions Abroad but Draw Cheers in Swing States
description: The president’s efforts to restrict Chinese imports and block a Japanese steel merger have pleased labor unions and sent a message to rival Donald J. Trump.
content: President Biden has intensified efforts to shield American industries from foreign competition in an election year, as he courts blue-collar workers and attempts to avoid being outflanked on trade by his Republican rival, former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Sweeney
title: Does My Body Need a Skin Care Routine?
description: Many people pay the most attention to the skin on their face, but the rest of your body needs care, too. Here’s how to give it what it needs.
content: Q: I’ve perfected a skin care routine for my face. Should I have something similar for the rest of my body?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: ‘Fire Shut Up in My Bones’ Review: A Met Milestone Returns
description: After making history as the Metropolitan Opera’s first work by a Black composer, Terence Blanchard’s “Fire” is back — with its showstopping step dance.
content: The Metropolitan Opera premiere of “Fire Shut Up in My Bones,” on Sept. 27, 2021, was a momentous event. Doubly so: “Fire” was the company’s first staged opera after an 18-month pandemic closure, and it was, after 138 years, its first work by a Black composer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Spring Cleaning
description: What are your favorite and least favorite household chores?
content: Is doing a big clean a spring ritual for you or your family? If so, what do you do? Do you look forward to this opportunity to spruce up your space each year? Or do you dread it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Doug Bock Clark
title: What Happened When Captain Cook Went Crazy
description: In “The Wide Wide Sea,” Hampton Sides offers a fuller picture of the British explorer’s final voyage to the Pacific islands.
content: In January 1779, when the British explorer James Cook sailed into a volcanic bay known by Hawaiians as “the Pathway of the Gods,” he beheld thousands of people seemingly waiting for him on shore. Once he came on land, people prostrated themselves and chanted “Lono,” the name of a Hawaiian deity. Cook was bewildered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 303
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Seth Meyers Slams Trump’s $50 Million Fund-Raiser
description: Meyers said the dinner menu at a Palm Beach campaign event for Donald Trump “had so many foreign words, I’m surprised he didn’t have it deported.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: sophomoric
description: This word has appeared in 18 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word sophomoric has appeared in 18 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 12 in “It’s a Birkin! No, a Dior. No, a Balenciaga. What in the World is It?” by Vanessa Friedman:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Rev. Cecil Murray, Leader Amid Los Angeles Riots, Dies at 94
description: He used his church, First African Methodist Episcopal, as a base to address the social ills that confronted the city’s Black population.
content: The Rev. Cecil Murray, a minister who turned a struggling church in Los Angeles into one of the country’s largest congregations, then made it a base to combat the many ills facing the city’s Black population — most notably during and after the 1992 riots — died on Friday at his home in the View Park-Windsor Hills section of Los Angeles. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Biden Condemns Arizona’s Abortion Ban as ‘Cruel’ and ‘Extreme’
description: President Biden, who promised to continue to fight for the restoration of Roe v. Wade, said the ban was first enacted “well before women had secured the right to vote.”
content: President Biden condemned a decision by Arizona’s Supreme Court on Tuesday to uphold an 1864 ban on nearly all abortions as “cruel” and “extreme,” saying the law was first enacted well before women even had the right to vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Cameron, on U.S. Trip, Takes a Risk and Meets With Trump
description: David Cameron, the British foreign secretary, said he spoke with Donald Trump, the former, and possibly future, president, about Ukraine and the Israel-Gaza conflict.
content: When Britain’s foreign secretary, David Cameron, went to Washington on Tuesday, he made all the usual stops, from the State Department to Capitol Hill. But it was his pilgrimage to Palm Beach, Fla., where he met former President Donald J. Trump for dinner on Monday evening at Mar-a-Lago, that grabbed most of the attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Banks Made Big Climate Promises. A New Study Doubts They Work.
description: Using European Central Bank lending data, researchers said there was not evidence that voluntary commitments were effective in reducing emissions.
content: Two and half years ago, bankers and investors attended the United Nations climate summit in Glasgow, an annual event normally dominated by activists and policymakers. It was considered a milestone as the financial sector agreed to put its might into tackling climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Oksana Parafeniuk
title: A Drone Strike in Odesa Shatters a Family’s Life
description: Serhii Haidarzhy’s wife and son were killed when their apartment building was hit. He and their daughter survived. The tragedy has become a symbol in Ukraine of the war’s terrible toll on civilians.
content: In the photograph, Anna Haidarzhy and her 4-month-old son, Tymofii, are barely visible under the bloodstained blanket. They lie in the rubble, at the feet of rescue workers in black and fluorescent uniforms. Just two arms, one from the mother, 31, one from her son, can be seen sticking out of the blanket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy and Kellen Browning
title: Arizona Reinstates 160-Year-Old Abortion Ban
description: The state’s highest court said the law, moribund for decades under Roe v. Wade, was now enforceable, but it put its decision on hold for a lower court to hear other challenges to the law.
content: Arizona’s highest court on Tuesday upheld an 1864 law that bans nearly all abortions, a decision that could have far-reaching consequences for women’s health care and election-year politics in a critical battleground state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Xi Meets With Russia’s Foreign Minister, Reaffirming Ties
description: The visit came days after the U.S. threatened new sanctions against Chinese companies if they aided Russia’s war in Ukraine.
content: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, and Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, met in Beijing on Tuesday, in a session seen as laying the groundwork for an expected visit to China by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and pushing back against mounting pressure from the United States and its allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi, Ronen Bergman and Eric Schmitt
title: Iran Smuggles Arms to West Bank, Officials Say, to Foment Unrest With Israel
description: The covert operation, described by U.S., Iranian and Israeli officials, is heightening concerns that Iran is seeking to turn the West Bank into a flashpoint in its shadow war with Israel.
content: Iran is operating a clandestine smuggling route across the Middle East, employing intelligence operatives, militants and criminal gangs, to deliver weapons to Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, according to officials from the United States, Israel and Iran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: How Often Do You Take Breaks From Your Phone?
description: What strategies do you use to have a healthier relationship with your devices?
content: Would you say you have a healthy relationship with your phone?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Elizabeth Dias
title: On Abortion, Trump Chose Politics Over Principles. Will It Matter?
description: With his video statement on Monday, Donald Trump laid bare how faulty a messenger he had always been for the anti-abortion cause.
content: When Donald J. Trump ran for president in 2016, the leaders of the anti-abortion movement extracted a series of promises from him in exchange for backing his nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Roy
title: These Scientists Rock. Literally.
description: The Pasteur Institute in Paris, known for its world-altering scientific research, has been making advancements in another field: the musical arts.
content: The Pasteur Institute, since opening in the 15th Arrondissement in Paris in the late 1880s, has been recognized for world-altering scientific discoveries. The institute, named for Louis Pasteur, the pioneering French scientist who founded it, has contributed to the production of vaccines for tetanus and the flu and was at the forefront of discovering the virus that causes AIDS.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: Trevor Griffiths, Marxist Writer for Stage and Screen, Dies at 88
description: For him, “art played a particular role in social change,” the director Mehmet Ergen said. “Everything was political.”
content: Trevor Griffiths, a prolific and avowedly Marxist writer for stage and screen most widely known for his play “Comedians,” which was staged in London and on Broadway, died on March 29 at his home in Yorkshire, England. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Caldwell
title: Everyone Wants to Seize Russia’s Money. It’s a Terrible Idea.
description: The dollar is probably the most valuable strategic asset the United States has.
content: The Republican House speaker, Mike Johnson, has brought a glimmer of hope to supporters of the Ukrainian war effort. He suggested to Fox News on March 31 that he would try to rally his divided party behind the REPO Act. That piece of legislation would allow President Biden, working with European allies, to seize Russian currency reserves frozen in the West and use them to aid Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azeen Ghorayshi
title: Youth Gender Medications Limited in England, Part of Big Shift in Europe
description: Five European countries have recently restricted hormone treatments for adolescents with gender distress. They have not banned the care, unlike many U.S. states.
content: The National Health Service in England started restricting gender treatments for children this month, making it the fifth European country to limit the medications because of a lack of evidence of their benefits and concern about long-term harms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Office Subs
description: Caroline Sommers and Freddie Cheng place a few orders.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Courts Caregivers, Pledging to Expand Support if He Is Re-elected
description: The president called for 12 weeks of paid family or medical leave, large investments in preschool for 4-year-olds and the extension of a child tax credit.
content: President Biden promised on Tuesday to continue pushing to expand child care subsidies, early education and paid medical leave, agenda items left unfulfilled during his three and a half years in the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: 50 Years After Historic Home Run, Hank Aaron Gets a Stamp and a Statue
description: The baseball legend hit his record-breaking home run on April 8, 1974. His statue will be unveiled at the Baseball Hall of Fame in May.
content: Hank Aaron, the celebrated baseball player who faced down racism as he broke the Major League Baseball record for most career home runs, was honored on Monday with a United States Postal Service Forever stamp and a statue at baseball’s Hall of Fame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Tesla Settles Lawsuit Over a Fatal Crash Involving Autopilot
description: A Tesla driver’s family had sought damages for the 2018 crash, which happened while the carmaker’s driver-assistance software was in use.
content: Tesla on Monday settled a lawsuit that blamed the automaker’s driver-assistance software for the death of a California man in 2018, averting a trial that would have focused attention on the company’s technology several months before it plans to unveil a self-driving taxi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Emma Bubola
title: In Landmark Climate Ruling, European Court Faults Switzerland
description: Experts said it was the first time an international court determined that governments were legally obligated to meet their climate targets under human rights law.
content: Europe’s top human rights court said on Tuesday that the Swiss government had violated its citizens’ human rights by not doing enough to stop climate change, a landmark ruling that experts said could bolster activists hoping to use human rights law to hold governments to account.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Fortune Magazine Names a New C.E.O.
description: Anastasia Nyrkovskaya, who was the chief financial officer and chief strategy officer, is the first woman to run the company.
content: Fortune named Anastasia Nyrkovskaya as its next chief executive on Tuesday, making her the first woman to lead the 95-year-old business publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Finch
title: Two Women, United by Climate Change and the Man They Both Married
description: In her far-reaching latest novel, “The Limits,” Nell Freudenberger forges connections between the global and the familial.
content: “The future is already here,” goes a line usually attributed to William Gibson. “It’s just not very evenly distributed.” So it can seem with climate change. Floods in Libya, temperatures above 125 degrees in China and Iran, wildfires across Hawaii and Canada and Tenerife: Those of us lucky enough not to be directly affected by these multiplying events can only watch from the intimate but infinite distance of our phone screens, a peculiarly modern kind of powerlessness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson Lund
title: The Fidelity of ‘Originalist’ Justices Is About to Be Tested
description: Will the court’s conservatives flinch in the face of two polarizing gun cases?
content: The Supreme Court reputedly has a long-awaited conservative majority committed to enforcing the meaning of the Constitution as it was understood when it was adopted. This commitment to originalist interpretation will soon be tested in two cases now before the court that have what lawyers call bad optics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle
title: Beeper Messaging App Is Acquired as a Bet on a Regulatory Shift
description: Automattic, the company behind WordPress.com, bought Beeper in an effort to build a system that works across Android and Apple devices.
content: Beeper, the app that brought iPhone messaging features to Android smartphones, has been acquired by Automattic, the company behind WordPress.com, to support the development of a single service for sending and receiving chats from WhatsApp, Signal, LinkedIn and others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Craig Marks
title: How Ozempic Turned a 1970s Hit Into an Inescapable Jingle
description: The diabetes drug has become a phenomenon, and “Oh, oh, oh, Ozempic!” — a takeoff of the Pilot song “Magic” — has played a big part in its story.
content: In February 2023, David Paton, guitar case in hand, strode across the most famous pedestrian walkway in rock history and into London’s Abbey Road Studios.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Considine
title: ‘Fallout’ Finds the Fun in an Apocalyptic Hellscape
description: TV’s latest big-ticket video game adaptation, from the creators of “Westworld,” takes a satirical, self-aware approach to the End Times.
content: The scream was just right — bloodcurdling, if also very funny — and the practical effects crew had finally found the proper volume and trajectory of the water cannon. The idea was to film what might happen if you ripped a man from the throat of a mutant salamander, exploding its guts like a giant water balloon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Catie Edmondson
title: Capitol Police Hire Special Prosecutors to Handle Rise in Threats Against Congress
description: The police department charged with protecting lawmakers has brought in new attorneys specially responsible for prosecuting people who make violent threats against members of Congress.
content: The Capitol Police, facing a flood of violent threats against members of Congress that is expected to rise with the upcoming November elections, have begun hiring prosecutors dedicated to going after people who threaten lawmakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassidy George
title: These Perfumes Come With Notes of Blood, Latex and Floorboards
description: For a growing number of fragrance fans, smelling singular is more important than smelling good.
content: After the New York City-based perfume brand Le Labo launched its best-selling scent Santal 33 in 2011, a fragrant chemtrail of fig, leather and sandalwood wafted across Lower Manhattan and Williamsburg, invisibly mapping the presence of fashionable people and places. For a period of time, for certain circles of New Yorkers, encountering Santal 33 was a near-daily occurrence at art galleries, clothing stores and cocktail bars. In 2017, when the New York-based beauty brand Glossier released You, with its lighter, brighter and spicy-sweet notes, that perfume began to take Santal 33’s place as the ubiquitous scent of trend-conscious young people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason DeParle
title: Another Red-Blue Divide: Money to Feed Kids in the Summer
description: Congress passed bipartisan legislation to provide families that rely on subsidized school meals with help buying food over the summer. Nearly half of Republican-led states have yet to sign on.
content: The governor was firm: Nebraska would reject the new federal money for summer meals. The state already fed a small number of children when schools closed. He would not sign on to a program to provide all families that received free or cut-rate school meals with cards to buy groceries during the summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: A Conductor Who Believes That No Artist Can Be Apolitical
description: At Munich’s prestigious opera house, the Russian-born Vladimir Jurowski has broadened the repertoire while rooting his work in political awareness.
content: One by one, the singers came out to bow. They had just finished a performance of Mieczyslaw Weinberg’s little-known “The Passenger,” at the Bayerische Staatsoper, or Bavarian State Opera. Each received not just respectful, but also enthusiastic applause. The loudest cheers, though, were reserved for the conductor: Vladimir Jurowski.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: A day after Trump’s abortion statement, Arizona awaits a key ruling.
description: A day after former President Donald J. Trump dominated headlines with a statement declaring that abortion policies should be left to the states, the issue will continue to be at the forefront of the nation’s political conversation.
content: A day after former President Donald J. Trump dominated headlines with a statement declaring that abortion policies should be left to the states, the issue will continue to be at the forefront of the nation’s political conversation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Gazans Still Face Extreme Hardship as the Pace of Fighting Slows
description: Though Israel recently withdrew troops from southern Gaza, cease-fire negotiations continue and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu repeated his vow to invade Rafah.
content: In early March, the Muslim holy month of Ramadan began amid dashed hopes that negotiators would reach a deal for a pause in the fighting in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Why Oil Prices Have Been Rising Recently
description: The increase this year, prompted by geopolitical worries and supply constraints, has sent gasoline prices higher and could hamper efforts to tame inflation.
content: Oil prices have climbed in recent weeks, spurred by concerns over supplies and geopolitical risks, including wars in Ukraine and the Middle East. Analysts say the momentum could carry prices higher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer, Nicholas Nehamas and Reid J. Epstein
title: Abortion Jumps to the Center of Arizona’s Key 2024 Races
description: Democrats quickly aimed to capitalize on a ruling by the state’s highest court upholding an 1864 law that bans nearly all abortions.
content: Democrats seized on a ruling on Tuesday by Arizona’s highest court upholding an 1864 law that bans nearly all abortions, setting up a fierce political fight over the issue that is likely to dominate the presidential election and a pivotal Senate race in a crucial battleground state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Dowling
title: Fjords, Pharaohs or Koalas? Time to Plan for Your Next Eclipse.
description: If you can’t get enough of totality, or missed out this time, you’ll have three more chances in the next four years in destinations like Iceland, Spain, Egypt and Australia.
content: Are you still a little giddy from the magical moments of totality during Monday’s solar eclipse? Or did clouds swoop in to block your view? Maybe you just couldn’t make it to the path of totality this time. No matter what, the question now is “Where and when will it happen again?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: How Low Will They Go? Wall Street’s Big Rethink on Interest Rate Cuts
description: Investors see Wednesday’s Consumer Price Index report as a pivotal report card on inflation and the Federal Reserve’s next move.
content: The mood music on rate cuts has changed again. Inflation hasn’t fallen as quickly as expected and the economy is performing strongly. All eyes now are focused on the upcoming Consumer Price Index data for clues on when the Fed might finally start cutting interest rates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Food Aid Program for Mothers and Children Will Provide More Fruits and Vegetables
description: The Agriculture Department updated the WIC program to more closely align with nutrition guidelines. The changes also reduce assistance for milk and juice.
content: The Agriculture Department said on Tuesday that low-income women and children eligible for a food aid program would receive more cash for purchases of fruits and vegetables, with less assistance available for milk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: The Sounds That Made Her Move: ‘Music Fed My Life Force’
description: The choreographer Dianne McIntyre presents “In the Same Tongue,” a dance she calls “an artistic history of myself,” at the new Apollo Stages at the Victoria Theater.
content: It was the 1970s, and Dianne McIntyre was a dancer on a mission: to soak up live music, specifically, she said, “so-called avant-garde jazz,” free jazz or, when labels really start to irritate her, just “whatever.” Shows would end late, making this obsession a sunrise pursuit. “We’d leave at 2 a.m., get on the subway from Brooklyn or down in the Village,” she said in a video interview. “At 2 a.m., the subways came by very seldom, so we’d get home at 4 a.m., something like that. But we didn’t care. We had to go. We had to go hear the music.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: The U.S. Urgently Needs a Bigger Grid. Here’s a Fast Solution.
description: A rarely used technique to upgrade old power lines could play a big role in fixing one of the largest obstacles facing clean energy, two reports found.
content: One of the biggest obstacles to expanding clean energy in the United States is a lack of power lines. Building new transmission lines can take a decade or more because of permitting delays and local opposition. But there may be a faster, cheaper solution, according to two reports released Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Vognar
title: A New Film Examines the Godfather of Modern Conservatism
description: The PBS documentary “The Incomparable Mr. Buckley” implicitly and explicitly asks: What would William F. Buckley think of today’s Republican Party?
content: William F. Buckley Jr., widely considered the godfather of modern conservatism, defended Joseph McCarthy and his communist witch hunts. He praised the “restraint” of Alabama law enforcement officers who brutally assaulted civil rights marchers on the Edmund Pettus Bridge in 1965. He was also a silver-tongued intellectual who abhorred boorish thinking and behavior and savored debates with the sharpest minds of his era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and Tracey Tully
title: Nadine Menendez Reveals ‘Serious Medical’ Issue and Asks for Trial Delay
description: Ms. Menendez, the wife of Senator Robert Menendez, needs surgery, leaving her unable to prepare for a May 6 trial on bribery charges, her lawyers said.
content: Nadine Menendez, the wife of Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey, asked a judge on Tuesday to delay her trial on bribery charges because of what her lawyers described as a “serious medical condition” that will require surgery and an extended recovery period.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Stumbling Into Goldilocks
description: How America avoided recession (so far).
content: The U.S. economy has been far more successful at recovering from the Covid shock than it was in dealing with the aftermath of the housing bubble of the 2000s. As I noted in my latest column, four years after the 2007-9 recession began, employment was still five million below its pre-recession peak. This time it’s up by almost six million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: TV Networks to Urge Biden and Trump to Debate, Wading Into a Fraught Topic
description: Speculation has swirled in the political world about whether the presumptive candidates will agree to the traditional face-to-face events, a campaign staple since 1976.
content: In an unusual move, the five major broadcast and cable news networks have prepared a joint open letter that urges President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump to participate in televised debates ahead of Election Day, according to two people with direct knowledge of their plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Turkey Restricts Exports to Israel in Protest of War in Gaza
description: Turkey announced limits on dozens of products, including cement and jet fuel, prompting Israel to threaten retaliatory trade measures.
content: Turkey said on Tuesday that it would restrict exports to Israel until there is a cease-fire in Gaza, prompting threats of a tit-for-tat response from a government with which it has long had tense relations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Heartbreak and Family Love on the International Booker Prize Shortlist
description: Books by Jenny Erpenbeck and Hwang Sok-yong are among six nominees for the prestigious award for translated fiction.
content: A novel about a woman grieving her twin and another tracing North and South Korean history through a family of railway workers are among the six titles nominated for this year’s International Booker Prize, the prestigious award for fiction translated into English.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Man Who Snuffed Out Abortion Rights Is Here to Tell You He Is a Moderate
description: He landed a major blow against legal abortion during his first term. If given a second, he will land another.
content: Donald Trump does not speak from conviction. He does not speak from belief or at least any belief other than self-obsession. He certainly does not speak from anything we might recognize as reason; when he’s holding forth at a microphone, even the most careful students of Trump the rhetorician will struggle to find the light of complex thought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Ben Protess
title: Trump’s Attempt to Delay Trial Is Denied by Appeals Court Judge
description: Donald Trump could try to have his request reviewed by a full judicial panel, but the opening of his case remains scheduled for Monday.
content: A New York appeals court judge on Tuesday rejected Donald J. Trump’s latest attempt to delay his criminal case in Manhattan, another blow to the former president’s increasingly desperate attempts to prevent the trial from starting next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Eclipse day in North America.
content: The first total solar eclipse in seven years plunged the day into darkness in Mexico, Canada and the U.S. yesterday, reminding millions of sky gazers of our planet’s place in the cosmos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Beut Takes a Modern Approach to Korean Royal Court Cuisine
description: Sawa brings Lebanese dishes to Park Slope, Brooklyn; Zaab Burger combines smash burgers and Thai flavors at Essex Market and more restaurant news.
content: Korean Royal Court cuisine from the Joseon Dynasty (1392 to about 1900) inspired this tasting-menu restaurant owned by Sarah Kang, the pastry chef here and formerly of Joomak Banjum, the now-closed, Michelin-starred restaurant. An eight-course menu ($125) reflects the opulence of the bygone era through a modern lens by the executive chef, Sang Hoon Jeong. Lobster and Wagyu, not necessarily palace fare in the past, share the menu with more typical abalone with rice porridge, and a royal hot pot with scallops. Lobster three ways using meat, shells and offal demonstrates a tradition of letting nothing go to waste. The dining room is done in muted grays with several seating areas. (Opens Wednesday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: ‘He’s Always Been Hungry for This’: Meet Ireland’s Youngest Ever Leader
description: After a swift political rise, Simon Harris, 37, was confirmed as Ireland’s premier. But his time as head of the government could be short.
content: Simon Harris was three years into a university degree when he dropped out in 2008.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Netanyahu Must Go
description: Being pro-Israel doesn’t entail slavish support for any leader of the country, particularly its most failed one.
content: It’s no secret to readers of this column where I stand on Israel’s war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: How the Solar Eclipse Affected Eid Timing
description: Some Muslim communities rely on a centuries-old method to determine when Ramadan ends: a crescent moon. That method was harder to follow this year.
content: For centuries, the sighting of a crescent moon has signaled the end of Ramadan, the holy month of fast and prayer for Muslims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Krysten Chambrot
title: Rut-Busting Recipes for Freezer Staples
description: Spicy ground turkey with snap peas, broccoli-walnut pesto pasta and sazón chicken breasts make frozen standbys sing.
content: Hi, all! This is Krysten, filling in for Emily, who’s back next week after a glorious spring break.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: 2 Men Fined $1.25 Million for Robocall Scheme to Suppress Black Vote
description: Right-wing operatives were behind the calls, which falsely claimed that people who voted by mail would have their information sent to law enforcement agencies.
content: Two right-wing political operatives who used a robocall campaign to try to discourage Black New Yorkers from voting in the 2020 election will pay up to $1.25 million for their actions, the New York State attorney general’s office announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Doug Mills
title: To Choose the Menu, Just Win the Masters
description: The winner of the most hallowed event in professional golf gets to design the menu (and pay) for the next year’s champions dinner. Jon Rahm, the 2023 winner, supplied a recipe from his grandmother.
content: The winner of the Masters Tournament gets a green jacket, an elegantly engraved trophy and a lifetime invitation to play one of the most revered events in professional golf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Downtown Los Angeles Places Another Big Bet on the Arts
description: The pandemic was tough on city centers and cultural institutions. What does that mean for Los Angeles, whose downtown depends on the arts?
content: For decades the effort to revitalize downtown Los Angeles has been tied to arts projects, from the construction of the midcentury modern Music Center in 1964 to the addition of Frank Gehry’s soaring stainless steel Walt Disney Concert Hall in 2003.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Walker Mimms
title: A Heartland Godmother of Installation Art, No Longer in the Shadows
description: She is a trailblazer of the architectural sculpture movement, and her diaries rival Frida Kahlo’s. Are we ready for the unsettling clarity of Donna Dennis?
content: One of Donna Dennis’s architectural installations — a false tunnel entrance installed on the Mad River — so confounded local Ohioans that one morning in August 1981, someone pipe-bombed it. New York’s bomb squad confiscated part of another structure, a cabin occupying City Hall Park, in 1986. The works by Dennis are so faithful to existing vocabularies of infrastructure that they defy classification as art objects.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Everything’s Fine, Potatoes in Line
description: In the midst of a political and environmental dispute between the Czech Republic and Poland over a coal mine, a potato salad contest is held in a small border town.

title: Election Officials Continue to Face Violent Threats
description: The New York Times received a file containing hundreds of violent messages against the Colorado secretary of state. Nick Corasaniti, a politics reporter for The New York Times, found that election officials across the country are facing a barrage of threatening messages.
